text: Talking about being sick is an important topic in English, especially if you need to visit a doctor or explain how you feel to someone.
Let's go over some useful phrases and vocabulary that can help you in these situations.
When you are feeling unwell, it's important to describe your symptoms clearly.
Here are some common ways to talk about them.
I have a headache.
I have a sore throat.
I'm feeling nauseous.
I have a cough and a fever.
My stomach hurts.
You may also need to explain how long you've been feeling sick.
I've been feeling sick since yesterday.
I've had a cold for two days.
I've been coughing all week.
When visiting a doctor, you might need to say why you are there.
I'm here because I've been feeling dizzy.
I need to see a doctor for my back pain.
I think I have the flu.
You can also explain how severe your symptoms are.
My headache is very bad.
The pain is mild, but it's constant.
I feel a little better today, but I'm still not well.
It's common to ask for advice when you're sick.
What should I do if my fever doesn't go down?
Is it okay to go to work with a cold?
Do you think I should see a doctor?
Here are some useful phrases that people use when talking about being sick.
I'm under the weather.
I caught a cold.
I'm feeling a bit off today.
I need to rest and recover.
Once you start feeling better, you can say,
I'm feeling much better now.
I'm almost back to normal.
I just need a couple more days to recover.
Practicing these phrases can help you feel more confident
when talking about being sick in English.
It's important to communicate clearly so that others can understand how you feel
and offer the right help.
